I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  2009  country  programming  mission,  the  Government  of  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) requested that the Asian Development Bank (ADB) provide technical 
assistance (TA) for Capacity Development for Rural Pension Administration and Services. A 
fact-finding mission for this TA visited Beijing from 15 to 19 March 2010, during which an 
understanding  was  reached  on  the  objectives,  scope,  terms  of  reference,  cost  estimates, 
financing  plan,  and  implementation  arrangements  of  this  TA.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  A lack of social security coverage for the elderly in rural areas exacerbates rural–urban 
economic disparity and concern about social instability in the PRC. According to the National 
Bureau of Statistics of China, over 55% of the country's population are rural residents, and 
almost two-thirds of the workforce is employed in rural areas. However, only about 10% of this 
rural workforce is covered by current rural pension schemes.  
 
3.   The  government  has  attempted  to  strengthen  old-age  protection  in  rural  areas  by 
introducing a rural pension system. The Ministry of Civil Affairs (MOCA) was in charge of 
implementation, promulgating a basic program for rural social security insurance at the county 
level in 1992. This program was established in more than 57% of townships, almost all counties, 
a little less than 75% of prefectures, and slightly more than 87% of provinces by the end of 1997. 
However, the government decided to abolish it in 1999, declaring that there were insufficient 
conditions in rural areas to carry out an extensive pension scheme.2 In the same year, authority 
for the rural pension system was also transferred from MOCA to the Ministry of Labor and 
Social Security, which has been reorganized into the Ministry of Human Resources and Social 
Security (MOHRSS). 
 
4.  Since then, several pilot rural pension schemes were implemented by local governments, 
which differed among areas according to their financial capacities and policy purposes. In 
general, these pilot systems were not very successful. Two major challenges were identified as 
obstacles to the establishment of effective rural pension systems in the PRC: (i) imperfect 
designs of rural pension systems,3 and (ii) lack of organizational capacity to conduct pension 
administration and services. 
 
5.  Then, in 2009, toward achieving its goal of a harmonious society, the central government 
again decided to improve old-age income security in rural areas. The State Council promulgated 
Guiding Principles on the Development of the New Rural Pension Pilot, and launched pilot 
projects in 10% of the counties in the PRC.4  
 
6.  For the successful implementation of the pilot projects and eventually the establishment 
of  an  effective  rural  pension  system,  ADB  launched  TA  for  Rural  Pension  Reform  and 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of the ADB website on 5 May 2010. 
2  According to the government, major risks involved in the implementation of this scheme were (i) financial risks from 
too-generous benefits, (ii) operational risks from weak administrative capacity, (iii) misleading information given to 
farmers, and (iv) social instability caused by the mismanagement of local governments. 
3  The most frequently mentioned problems are (i) insufficient pension benefits to protect post-retirement life, (ii) lack 
of portability of pension entitlement among different regions, and (iii) lack of government subsidies for pensioners.

2   
Development in 2009 (footnote 4). Through this TA, ADB is assisting the PRC in developing an 
effective institutional design for its rural pension system.5 However, for it to be successful, 
strengthening  institutional  capacity  for  implementing  pension  services  is  critical.  This  is 
especially the case for the PRC, since both the number of rural residents and the area that must 
be covered by the rural pension system are large. 
 
7.  Related  to  strengthening  the  institutional  capacity,  some  of  the  most  urgent  issues 
requiring policy makers' attention can be drawn from the implementation of the TA for Rural 
Pension Reform and Development and a review of past reform efforts. 
(i)  The issue lies in the underdeveloped capacity and insufficient number of public 
servants who handle rural pension services. Since the authority responsible for 
rural pension administration in local governments has not been well established,6 
staff members have not had the opportunity to develop the necessary capacity. 
In addition, in 2008, 2,860 county agencies had an average of five staff members 
each, while 41,040 agencies in townships had an average of one or two. 
(ii)  Operational standards are lacking, leading to increased management inefficiency 
as well as higher operational and investment risks. For example, there are no 
specific  standards  for  what  kind  of  information  needs  to  be  collected  from 
pension participants, when and how to collect it, how to transfer data and funds 
to different rural areas, and what information needs to be checked at pension 
delivery.  
(iii)  Systems for performance measurement and internal control are also absent. It is 
important to develop such systems not only because they help strengthen public 
confidence in the rural pension system, but also because they can develop staff 
capacity through monitoring and quality control. 
 
8.  Therefore,  for  the  successful  establishment  of  a  rural  pension  system  in  the  PRC, 
capacity development for rural pension agencies needs to be addressed, including a better 
financing strategy and appropriate human resources allocation. In addition, strategies need to 
be established for the integration of the segmented pension administration system by designing 
proper  operational  standards  and  setting  up  effective  mechanisms  for  performance 
measurement and internal control. This is consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy, 
2008–2010 to support social safety nets and a pension system in response to the demographic 
shift in the PRC.7 Furthermore, the TA will address inclusive growth and balanced development, 
as the better administration of the rural pension system will improve income security for elderly 
rural residents the majority of whom have been excluded from the pension coverage and help 
them share the benefits of national economic growth. 
 
                                                 
5  The TA aims to provide (i) an analysis of the sustainability of the rural pension system using a projection of its 
revenue and expenditure; (ii) an overview of the policy, legal, regulatory, and administrative frameworks of the rural 
pension system; and (iii) lessons in the areas of policy reform and formulation of operational procedures and 
technical parameters. 
6  Since  the  1998  institutional  reform  (para.  3),  rural  pension  administration  in  local  governments  has  been 
transferred from the Civil Affairs Department, which corresponds to the Ministry of Civil Affairs in the central 
government, to the Department of Human Resources and Social Security which corresponds to the Ministry of 
Human Resources and Social Security in the central government. However, since the consolidation process has 
not yet been completed, some counties have pension systems still under the Civil Affairs Department. 
7  ADB. 2008. Country Partnership Strategy: People's Republic of China, 2008–2010. Manila.

3
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact of the TA will be the establishment of a well-functioning rural pension system 
that provides basic income protection for the elderly rural population. The achievement of this 
impact will be demonstrated through the population's increased participation in the rural pension 
system. The TA's outcome will be the establishment of an efficient rural pension administration 
system with an appropriate level of resources, well-developed standards of practice, and well-
designed  systems  for  performance  measurement  and  internal  control.  Success  will  be 
measured by increased staff and budget for rural pension agencies; consistent operational 
procedure adopted by rural pension agencies; and improved quality of service delivery including 
shorter processing time and reduced incidents of mismanagement. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  Key activities of the TA will be comprised of two major parts. The first part will consist of 
the formulation of proposals on how to integrate rural pension administration agencies and on 
how to design a rural pension management and delivery system, including the setting up of 
agencies at township and village levels. The second part will consist of the identification of 
managerial issues that must be addressed, range of services that the system will deliver, 
detailed operational flows, and internal control measures.  
 
11.  The TA will involve extensive field surveys on the existing rural pension pilot projects to 
gather data on the current status of the rural pension system regarding its management, service 
delivery, and operational flows. The data from these surveys will be used as inputs into the 
process of designing a better rural pension system for the PRC. Targeted workshops and 
seminars  will  then  be  conducted  for  different  stakeholders  at  various  stages  of  TA 
implementation. In the initial stage, workshops will be held with the executing agency to discuss 
the feasibility and viability of the TA implementation plan. After field studies of typical areas have 
been  completed,  workshops  will  be  organized  to  discuss  lessons  learned  and  to  identify 
directions for next steps. Seminars will also be held for government officials and specialists in 
relevant fields to gather their inputs on draft reports. 
 
12.  The TA outputs will be one overview report, two thematic reports, one draft policy 
document on standards of practice, and a series of policy notes as knowledge products. 
(i)  Report—Developing capacity for the management and service delivery of 
rural pensions in the People's Republic of China. The components of this 
report will include an overview of the historical development, current situation, 
and problems of the rural pension system; a discussion on strategies for its 
organizational structure, human resources allocation, and operational procedures; 
a  discussion  on  designing  internal  control  mechanisms;  and  an  analysis  on 
applying different management and service delivery models in rural areas in 
different  stages  of  economic  development.  The  report  will  also  provide 
recommendations for policy, legal and regulatory, and administrative reforms in 
the rural pension system in the PRC. 
(ii)  Thematic report I—Capacity building for rural pension agencies. This report 
will present the analyses and proposals for developing capacity in rural pension 
agencies. It will propose institutional designs, including sizes of organizations 
and allocation of human resources, and relevant policies for supporting their 
operation. It will consider the economic development stage of each area when

4   
proposing policy recommendations and providing suitable solutions, as needed, 
for their lack of human resources and funding. 
(iii)  Thematic report II—Operational steps and business flows of rural pension 
administration  in  the  People's  Republic  of  China.  This  report  will  be 
composed of four parts. The first part will identify the major activities at each 
operational stage of the rural pension system and propose standards on how to 
execute those activities. The second part will develop concrete performance 
indicators  for  each  operational  stage  and  design  workflows  following  those 
indicators.  The  third  part  will  develop  protocols  for  the  efficient  transfer  of 
pensioner rights among different rural areas. The fourth part will propose the 
mechanisms for checking fund flows among individual accounts, government 
subsidies,  and  collective  subsidies  as  well  as  for  enhancing  the  security  of 
accounts. 
(iv)  Standards of practice on operational steps and business flows of rural 
pension administration in the People's Republic of China. This document will 
be the basis of the policy document. It will be drafted based on all of the above 
research outcomes. It will serve as specific guidelines for MOHRSS and rural 
governments to implement and monitor rural pension systems. 
(v)  A series of policy notes geared toward higher level policy and decision 
makers. Based on the results from workshops and seminars sponsored by the 
TA, a series of policy notes on relevant issues such as setting up rural pension 
agencies and designing operational procedures will be produced.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $700,000 equivalent. The government has requested ADB 
to finance $500,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Special Fund (TASF–Others). The government will provide in-kind contribution of 
$200,000, through the provision of miscellaneous expenses such as office accommodation, 
transport, and office supplies. Detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The proposed executing agency is MOHRSS. An interdepartmental working group will 
be  set  up  within  MOHRSS,  comprising  the  Information  Center,  International  Cooperation 
Department, Rural Pension Department, and Social Insurance Administration. Other ministries 
and agencies to be regularly consulted during the project implementation include the Ministry of 
Finance and the National Development and Reform Commission. The MOHRSS will provide the 
necessary office space, counterpart staff, transport, and other services to the consultants and 
will arrange appointments for the consultants with relevant agencies and organizations.  
 
15.  The TA will engage one international consultant and four national consultants for a total 
of 30 person-months. The national rural pension administration and services specialist will be 
the  team  leader.  Outline  terms  of  reference  for  the  consultants  are  in  Appendix  3.  The 
international and national consultants will be selected and engaged on an individual basis in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time).  The  proceeds  of  the  TA  will  be  disbursed  in  line  with  the  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). For training seminars and 
conferences, an advance payment facility may be used.

5
16.  The TA is expected to begin in November 2010 and end in October 2011. The TA will be 
implemented  in  four  phases.  The  first  phase  will  involve  implementation  planning  and 
determination of pilot locations in the central and western regions, and will be completed in 3 
months. The second phase will involve the conduct of field studies, surveys, and workshops for 
reviewing the preliminary findings, to be completed in another 3 months. The third phase will be 
preparation of draft final reports, which will take another 3 months. The fourth and final phase, 
during which the final workshop will be conducted and the TA outputs will be completed, will 
take up the final 3-month period. 
 
17.  In  addition  to  the  main  outputs,  the  consultants  will  submit  to  both  ADB  and  the 
MOHRSS  (i)  inception  reports  2  weeks  after  commencement  of  their  services,  (ii)  interim 
progress reports at appropriate stages during TA implementation, (iii) draft final reports before 
the conclusion of the contract, and (iv) final reports 2 weeks after receiving comments from the 
MOHRSS and ADB. All reports must be submitted in English and Mandarin. Workshops will be 
organized  periodically  for  dissemination  of  consultant  findings  and  discussion  of  policy 
recommendations. 
 
18.  Major project activities will be regularly monitored and reported on by the MOHRSS and 
ADB missions. Consultant reports will be presented at workshops and seminars organized for 
the validation of findings. Reports will be made available on the ADB website in English and 
Mandarin, if appropriate, and published whenever appropriate. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Capacity Development for Rural Pension 
Administration and Services, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  For this technical assistance (TA) activity, the international consultant will be primarily 
responsible for introducing international experiences and best practices, providing advisory 
services  on  key  technical  issues,  and  disseminating  lessons  learned  and  providing 
recommendations to policy makers. National consultants will be responsible for all technical 
aspects of TA implementation and training. 
A.  Rural Pension Development Specialist (international, 4 person-months) 
2.  This consultant must possess good knowledge of and sufficient experience in areas 
related to rural pension development both in the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and other 
countries. A strong academic background, with publishing experience of relevant materials, is 
preferred. Knowledge of Mandarin and experience in international cooperative research are 
advantages. Specifically, the consultant will 
(i)  introduce experiences of and draft a background report on rural pension reform 
and development in other countries for PRC policy makers to help them grasp 
key success factors and be mindful of potential areas of failure; 
(ii)  provide  necessary  background  materials  related  to  rural  pension  reform 
programs  in  other  countries,  and  introduce  to  policy  makers  and  national 
consultants how to best handle issues such as pension administration, service 
delivery, and internal control; 
(iii)  recommend better options for streamlining the administrative structure of the 
rural pension system; 
(iv)  identify potential missing areas that the executing agency, the Ministry of Human 
Resources and Social Securities (MOHRSS), and consulting team must address 
to ensure a successful rural pension system; 
(v)  advise and participate with national consultants in designing and implementing a 
survey  on  the  current  status  of  the  rural  pension  system  regarding  its 
management, service delivery, and operational flows; 
(vi)  prepare relevant sections of the report, and advise national consultants during 
their preparation of final reports; 
(vii)  prepare policy notes and technical notes for relevant issues;  
(viii)  participate in the drafting of the report; 
(ix)  assist the MOHRSS and national consultants in identifying key issues to be 
covered in workshops and seminars, in preparing background materials, and in 
recommending resource persons; and 
(x)  deliver sessions during training workshops regarding international experiences 
with rural pension programs. 
B.  National Consultants (26 person-months) 
 
3.  National consultants with in-depth country and sector knowledge and solid backgrounds 
in rural pension issues will be recruited. They are also expected to assume key responsibilities 
in leading the consulting team and in conducting surveys and training activities for local social 
security administrations. Knowledge of English is required.

10  Appendix 3 
1.  Rural Pension Administration and Services Specialist and Team Leader (9 
person-months) 
 
4.  The consultant will assume the role of the team leader and be responsible for overall TA 
management, timely delivery of good-quality reports, identification and management of source 
persons for various technical tasks, and organization of workshops and training activities. The 
consultant  must  be  experienced  in  project  management,  particularly  that  assisted  by 
international organizations, and have a solid background in rural social security theory and 
practices  as  well  as  quantitative  evaluation  methodology  on  the  efficiency  of  public 
administration issues. The consultant must be knowledgeable of the latest urban and rural 
pension reform issues and public service administration reform issues in the PRC. In addition, 
the consultant will 
(i)  review past and current rural pension reform systems, and identify the main 
issues that need to be addressed in the current round of pilot projects; 
(ii)  together  with  the  international  rural  pension  development  specialist,  identify 
elements that will affect the efficient implementation of a rural pension system in 
the  PRC,  as  well  as  policy  conditions  needed  for  the  development  of  a 
sustainable and effective rural pension system; 
(iii)  develop ideas on integrating the rural pension agencies and setting up such 
agencies at the township and village levels; 
(iv)  recommend better options for streamlining the administrative structure of the 
rural pension system; 
(v)  design  questionnaires,  and  organize  surveys  of  stakeholders  for  designing 
efficient pension management and service delivery procedures; 
(vi)  liaise with government statistic bureaus and other sources of public information 
to gather data that are necessary for streamlining administrative procedures and 
rural pension system monitoring;  
(vii)  coordinate  with  various  government  agencies  and  other  stakeholders  for 
consultation and consensus building; 
(viii)  prepare the report, two thematic reports, and draft policy document; 
(ix)  prepare policy notes and technical notes for relevant issues; 
(x)  advise other national consultants during their preparation of thematic reports; and 
(xi)  deliver relevant sessions in associated training workshops. 
2.  Rural Pension Operation and Work Flow Specialist (6 person-months)  
5.  The  consultant  will  assume  overall  responsibility  for  designing  the  operation  and 
workflow of the rural pension system in the PRC. The consultant must have a good command of 
social security theory, and have experience in quality and business flow control. Specifically, the 
consultant will 
(i)  analyze the operational flow of the rural pension system; 
(ii)  design an optimized operational flow plan for the rural pension system; 
(iii)  assist in drafting the report, thematic reports, and draft policy document;  
(iv)  prepare policy notes and technical notes for relevant issues; and 
(v)  deliver sessions during training workshops on operation flow issues. 
3.  Rural Pension Fund Flow Specialist (4 person-months)
